newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss toughen stance on Iran after German verdict.
newsitem.headline: Swiss toughen stance on Iran after German verdict.

text.p: Switzerland said on Wednesday it would take a harder line with Iran but still maintain ties after a German court ruled that Tehran ordered the 1992 murders of four Kurdish activists.

It recommended Swiss organisers cancel a planned seminar next month on investment in Iran and suspended consideration of opening a human rights dialogue with the Islamic government, the Berne foreign ministry said in a statement.
It said it would decide only later whether to keep its envoy to Iran at home for more consultations when the ambasador returns from a trip to the United States later this month.

"The Berlin verdict in the so-called Mykonos trial has shown that a case of state terrorism was proven," triggering consequences far beyond bilateral ties between Iran and Germany, the ministry statement said.
"The Federal Council (cabinet) is thus strengthening is already very critical stance on Iran while maintaining ties."
It ruled out opening human rights talks with Iran "because the conditions for a constructive human rights dialogue are not seen as being fulfilled".
Berne advised the Swiss Trade Promotion Bureau to scrap its Iran investment seminar on May 5 that Swiss federal trade officials had been set to attend.
Neutral Switzerland has represented U.S. diplomatic interests in Iran since the U.S. embassy in Tehran was seized by Iranian students in 1980.
Iran -- fighting U.S. sanctions and keen to preserve links with Europe -- has repeatedly denied any role in the Berlin killings, which it blames on fighting between opposition groups.

European Union member states, except Greece, said they would recall ambassadors for consultations and Iran said it would reciprocate. But both Bonn and Tehran indicated they did not want a total diplomatic break.
EU states have resisted U.S. pressure for sanctions on Iran, which Washington accuses of sponsoring terrorism. Tehran denies the charges.
